It is intended to engage a Project Consultant group composed of international and local firms, with community participation specialists with experience in the project area to assist: * the PMO in the administration, coordination and monitoring of all project activities; and * the four PMUs in carrying out the detailed engineering design and construction supervision in each of the four cities, with a process of community participation.
 112 ANNEX 12 HI. Scope of Work 4. In assisting the PMO and the four PMUs, the general scope of the services to be provided by the Project Consultant will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following: ProJect management and monitoring - which includes: (i) assistance to the PMO in general administration, coordination and monitoring of the Project including preparation of progress reports for World Bank and (ii) assistance to each PMU in carrying out the implementation and coordination activities specific to each city. * ~Beneficiaries participation press. details of which are described in Annex 13. This includes: (i) conducting field reconnaissance inspection to evaluate local conditions; (ii) preparing standard critena, procedures and guidelines for the four cities; (iii) managing the participation process to ascertain and negotiate with beneficiary groups the alternative option for connecting to the system; and (iv) incorporation of facilities the options selected by the beneficiaries in the detailed design and/or construction. * Design of facilities - which includes: (i) preparation of common criteria and standards for the four cities; (ii) conduct of topographical surveys and soil investigations; (iii) preparation of detailed engineering designs including detailed designs drawings and computations, tender documents and specifications; and (iv) any other design related activity including preparation of design reports. ~Construion of facilities - which includes: (i) assistance to each PMU for tendering of civil works and procurement of equipment and goods; and (ii) supervision of civil works construction. * Training of Operators and Start-up - which includes: (i) training to the Water Districts' staff responsible for O&M of the systems; and (ii) coordination with training to be provided by suppliers of equipment to ensure proper and timely start-up of operation. * Monitoring and Evaluation support - which includes assistance to: (i) the PMO in analyzing data and information provided by LGUs/WDs; and in preparing reports for World Bank; and (ii) the PMUsIWDs in collecting raw data for submission to the PMO and CPSO. IV. Tasks 5. The tasks to be performed under this Consultancy will include, but will not necessarily be limited to the following:
 113 ANNEX 12 EWsject Management and Monitoring 6. In the general administration, coordination and monitoring of Project implementation, the Project Consultant's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: (a) attend meetings concerning the implementation of the overall Project or individual projects if and when required by PMO, CPSO and/or the LGUs; (b) prepare critical path schedules for the overall Project and for each individual project and update them on a regular basis for monitoring implementation activities; (c) maintain records and minutes of all implementation-related activities; (d) review the technical aspects of claims and/or extra payments claimed by the contractors and suppliers and make recommendations thereon to each PMU and/or PMO if and when requested; (e) prepare monthly progress reports for PMOJPMUs summarizing implementation progress and the status of expenditures of the overall project and each individual project; (f) ensure upon completion of works that the contractors provide such records and manufacturers' manuals as are reasonably necessary for the operation and maintenance of the works; (g) inspect completed works and make recommendations to each PMU on the issuance of the certificate of completion. (h) prepare completion reports that evaluate actual implementation against planned implementation for the overall project and each individual project; (i) facilitate the Bank's review missions. Beeficiarie Participation Process 7. The Project Consultant will be required to carry out, at the commencement of the services, a reconnaissance survey in each of the four cities to identify the most suitable approach to be adopted for the participation process. The adopted approach should be based on the objectives and concepts outlined in Annex 13 - "The Community Participation Process", taking into due account the local conditions and social behavior of concerned communities.
 114 ANNEX 12 8. Depending on the approach adopted in each city, the Project Consultant will have to adjust/revise the following tasks: (a) undertake the preparatory activities in accordance with criteria and procedures agreed with community representatives and leaders during the reconnaissance survey. These activities should include preparation of information materials such as flip charts and visual aids, information dissemination, and setting up of meetings and workshops; (b) carry out orientation workshops and identify, in agreement with community leaders, homogeneous areas (purok/blocks), where alternative connection options will be designed and consultations with beneficiaries will be conducted; (c) prepare the conceptual design of expected connection options and define the corresponding design criteria for each option. Estimate cost and evaluate connection fees and monthly charges and identify any other detail which are needed for the users to understand benefits and constraints of each option; (d) prepare the detailed design of connection options including cost estimates, identify benefits, constraints and charges related to each option and define organizational and training requirements for the User Consultation Teams;; (e) organize and train the User Consultation Teams responsible for the presentation of options to the users; (f) direct and coordinate the User Consultation Teams in presenting available options to each purok/block and provide the beneficiaries all details necessary for them to choose the preferred option; (g) organize meetings for the selection of option and signing of agreements between the LGU of each city and the beneficiaries' representatives; (h) review results of the process and ensure that the selected connection options are included in the design and construction of each individual system. (i) carry out any additional or supplementary task necessary to achieve the objectives of the participation process.
 115 ANNEX 12 Design of Facilities 9. Detailed engineering design including tender documents will be prepared for each individual project city by the Project Consultant. Tasks will include, but not necessarily limited to, the following: (a) prepare common design criteria and standards for all individual projects to be used for the conduct of surveys and investigations and preparation of detailed engineering designs of the sewerage and sanitation facilities; (b) review the configurations of the proposed sewerage scheme as outlined in the feasibility study with due consideration given to land availability; (c) carry out detailed topographic surveys to prepare maps at: (i) 1:500/1:1000 scale (as appropriate) with ground elevations covering the area to be served by the sewerage system with all details concerning streets characteristics and type of pavement, location and type of houses and buildings, location of existing septic tanks, location and depth of drainage and water supply pipelines, location of electrical and telephone lines and any other public or private appurtenances; and (ii) 1:100/1:200/1:500 scale (as appropriate) for areas where facilities such as pumping stations, wastewater treatment plants, sanitation communal facilities, etc. have to be constructed, showing all details concerning existing structures, buildings, utility installations, etc.; (d) carry out soil investigations for the structural design of facilities and, if necessary, for excavation of pipelines at suitable intervals. With regard to the wastewater treatment plant the geotechnical investigations should recommend the most economic construction method by giving special consideration to locally available materials and local construction methods. Subsurface exploration shall consist of an appropriate number of borings and test pits at various strategic locations at the site also to determine the level of the underground water table. Standard logs and laboratory testing (moisture content, Attenberg limits, grain size and permeability coefficient, etc.) shall be done as required; (e) prepare the hydraulic and functional designs of the proposed facilities including wastewater treatment plant, pumping stations, and primary, secondary and tertiary sewers; (f) prepare detailed engineering designs and construction drawings of the sewerage and sanitation communal facilities including on site preparatory tasks, layout of facilities, simple architectural and landscape designs for pumping stations, wastewater treatment plants, foundation and structural works, pipeline construction, mechanical works including piping works
 116 ANNEX 12 and installation of pumps and other equipment, and electrical works including instrumentation and control system; (g) prepare bill of quantities and divide the procurement of civil works and equipment into an appropriate number of contract packages, taking into account that procurement of civil works and/or equipment will be done through either NCB or ICB, whichever applicable; (h) prepare the scope and detailed cost estimates for each contract broken down into foreign exchange cost and local currency cost; (i) prepare tender documents for each contract package, including general specifications and detailed technical specifications for materials, equipment, instrument, methods of construction of civil works and methods of installation and fabrication for mechanical and electrical works; (j) prepare a detailed construction management plan for construction of each individual project, test run and start-up of all facilities; (k) prepare a design report for each individual project presenting the results of all the above tasks including surveys and investigations as well as design computations. Construction of Facilities 10. Under this item, the Project Consultant will provide its services in two overlapping stages: the bidding stage and the construction stage. In assisting the PMUs during the bidding stage, the Consultant's task will include, but not necessarily limited to, provide guidelines and train, if necessary, the PMUs' staff to ensure that the tendering process is in accordance with World Bank's procedures or is acceptable to the Bank; 11. During construction the Project Consultant, on behalf of each PMU, will be responsible for field supervision of construction works carried out by contractors in each individual project. Tasks will include, but not be limited to, the following: (a) update or revise, if necessary, the construction management plan and the cost estimates based on the results of the bidding; (b) modify the design and construction drawings as necessary after the bidding and during construction; (c) supervise the mobilization of the contractor and delivery of materials and equipment;
 117 ANNEX 12 (d) review shop drawings prepared by the contractors and equipment manufacturers/ suppliers; (e) monitor the contractor's topographic surveys to ensure correct alignments and elevations of facilities, and soil tests to ensure adequate data for foundation design; (f) inspect materials and equipment delivered to the site of the works and witness tests of materials and equipment to be incorporated in the works, if necessary, at the manufacturer's premises; (g) supervise, inspect, measure and control the quality of the construction of works and the installation of equipment to ensure compliance with drawings and specifications; (h) inspect and approve all completed works and check contractor's completed or as-built schedule of quantities; (i) supervise the implementation of all safety and environmental protection measures; (i) maintain records of progress of works and the results of inspections and - - tests of materials and equipment; (k) issue instructions on behalf of and with approval of the PMU to the contractor and equipment suppliers in connection with the construction of the works and in accordance with the contract documents; (1) make recommendations to the PMU and issue instructions, with the approval of the PMU, to the contractor on the extent of special inspections and testing required and to be carried out in connection with the construction of works; (m) compare actual with scheduled progress, advise the PMU of any developments that could delay completion and recommend any necessary actions to be taken by the PMU to facilitate timely completion of construction works; (n) observe any change or previously unknown conditions that may require modifications to the design and/or specifications of the works, advise the PMU of the same, and recommend appropriate action; prepare any necessary extra work orders with the approval of the PMU; (o) review as-built drawings of the completed works to be prepared by the contractor;
 118 ANNEX 12 (p) supervise tests of major pipelines and equipment as well as start-up and commissioning; (q) prepare O&M manuals for all installed physical infrastructure including wastewater treatment plant, sewer system and appurtenances and communal sanitation facilities; (r) provide advice and suggestions to the PMU on the overall construction works; (s) assist the WD in defining the resources (personnel and cash flow) required for the proper operation and maintenance of the installed facilities. Trining of Operators and Start-up 12. The training program for the LGU/WD's staff aims at improving their capacity to operate and maintain the sewerage system and particularly the wastewater treatment plant of each individual project. The tasks required of the Project Consultant will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following: (a) prepare a detailed training program (including routine and corrective maintenance for sewers, pumping stations, wastewater treatment plants, etc.) to be carried out during the last part of the construction period; (b) organize and carry out separated training sessions for the staff of each individual project or, if feasible, combined sessions for the staff of two or more projects; (c) evaluate, during the start of operations, the training results and recommend additional training in specific areas, as may be necessary. V. Monitoring and Evaluation 13. The M&E system aims at providing managers with information on progress toward project objectives, impact on beneficiaries, and information on institutional, technical and financial aspects of the Project, and is described in Annex 8. 14. The tasks of the Project Consultant in this regard will include, but not be limited to, the following: (a) define the information that must be collected for review by managers for satisfactory financial and technical management of the implementation process (b) assist the LGUs/WDs and local communities in the collection of raw data for the indicators;
 119 ANNEX 12 (c) assist the LGUs/WDs in the preparation of specific reports to be submitted to the PMO and CPSO. (d) assist the PMO in analyzing data provided by LGUs/WDs and in monitoring financial terms and physical progress of project implementation; (e) recommend improvements in the collection of raw data, as necessary; (f) assist the PMO in preparing specific reports for World Bank. VI. Reporting Requirements 15. The Project Consultant, in addition to the design reports, shall observe the following reporting schedule: Social Part and Sanitary Education Program Reports - to be submitted monthly after the commencement of the services. ProJect Status Reports - to be submitted monthly after the commencement of the services. Progress Reports - to be submitted quarterly after the commencement of the services. Eroiect Comnletion Renor - to be submitted at the end of the services. 16. The Consultant will submit to PMO five copies of all above mentioned reports. VII. Time Table and Personnel Requirements 17. The services of the Project Consultant are expected to be provided cover a period of about 60 months. The team of the Consultant shall collectively have extensive experience in the relevant aspects of sewerage and sanitation engineering. It will be required to include specialists (preferably from local NGOs) with expertise in the field of beneficiary participation and involvement to ensure the implementation, in each city, of a demand-driven project. Additional experience in the management and administration of projects financed by multilateral development agencies would be an advantage. 18. The LBP, at it own cost, will provide counterpart administrative and professional staff and the Project Manager to the PMO.
 120 ANNEX 12 19. The LGU's , at there own cost, will provide counterpart administrative and professional staff to the PMU's and the PMU's Coordinator. 20. The staff to be provided by the consultant will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following. * counterpart Project Manager to the PMO, * counterparts to the PMU Coordinators, * Senior Sanitary or Civil Engineer, * Senior Community Participation Specialist, * Procurement Specialist, * Community Participation Specialists, * Sanitary or Civil Engineers, . Inspectors, . others. 21. The consultant shall provide a time table for carrying out the tasks as well as the staffing profile to be used, together with the corresponding person months. The information may be presented in a tabular form as follows:
 121 ANNEX 12 Table A 12.1 Staffing Requirements (in person-months) Personnel Cagayan de Calamba Cotabato Davao Total Oro Counterpart Project Manager to the PMO Counterpart to the PMU's Coordinators Sanitary or Civil Engineer in charge Community Participation Specialist in charge Procurement Specialist Community Participation Specialist Sanitary or Civil Engineer tapector Oters (as required) TOTAL Central and Local Offices of the Consultant 22. The Project Consultant will be required to establish a Central Project Office in Davao City and Local Offices in each of the other three cities. The Local Project Office for Davao will be established in the same premises as the Central Projects Office. 23. The Central Office will coordinate and direct the work of the local offices and will carry out all the activities common to the four projects, including preparation of guidelines, procedures, design criteria and standards, etc. The preparation of the tmnk detailed design and tender documents for the four projects will be done in the Central Office to maxinize the use of available resources and avoid duplication of efforts. 24. The Local Project Offices will be responsible for undertaking the project activities in the respective cities, including the beneficiaries participation process, the preparation of the feeder detailed design, the conduct of field activities such as surveys and investigations and construction supervision.
 122 ANNEX 12 25. In the Central Project Office will also be housed the PMO and the PMU of Davao. In each of the four Local Project Offices will be housed the respective PMU.
 123 ANNEX 13 PHILIPPINES WATER DISTRICTS DEVELOPMENT PROJECT The Community Participation Process in WDDP I. Basic Assumption 1. In defining the methodology for the WDDP community participation process the basic assumption was that the success of social programs lies in the interaction between the agents that promote such programs and their users. This is the only way of ensuring that sewerage and sanitation investments lead to sustainable services in the long run. The agents include the IBRD, the PMO/LBP, state and/or municipal governments, consultants, and contractors. The users are the communities and groups that will benefit directly from the program. 2. In the proposed interactive process, the agents that promote the programs must listen to the community, learn about its actual conditions, and implement projects that respond to the users preferences with regard to tariffs and service levels. The user community needs to be responsible for ensuring it is a fully equal participant in the planning and operation of facilities constructed. H. Methodology Used 3. WDDP takes a participative approach based on an active and continuous process of interaction between the beneficiaries and all the production agents involved, with a view to obtaining a common understanding of rights and responsibilities. 4. The following steps will be undertaken during the process: (a) Information dissemination takes place at all stages of a project, implying a continuous feedback process through which the community learns about potential activities in the area, and the agents to learn about community dynamics. (b) Discussion between the technical team and user groups will result in better comprehension of the issues. Working with this element in all stages of a project means integrating "popular wisdom" with "technical know-how". In other words, the agents and communities engage in an on-going discussion of the community situation and dynamics and technically viable activities. (c) Proposal and decision. This is the next stage in the process, and enables the project staff and the communities to reach closure on the final project design best suited to the community needs.
 124 ANNEX 13 (d) Responsibility: This is the final objective of the participative process, in which the project team and the public make a commitment, with the former undertaking to provide sanitation systems that are suited to the community's preferences and willingness to pay. The users' commitment to pay for the service, use the systems carefully, and pay for the maintenance of the equipment is guaranteed by community groups at the block, purok or barangay levels. III. Stages of Work 5. Methodologically, the community participation process is divided into stages coinciding with the stages of the project cycle, although some of the stages can be carried out concurrently. 6. Stage One. Description of the Area. This stage precedes the works and constitutes the first contact with the community. It involves identification of formal and informal community representatives and leaders for negotiations, leading to formal agreements for performance of the work. In this stage, the community is informed about the work. Use is made of community resources, vehicle-mounted loudspeakers, newspapers, community radio programs, religious organizations, etc. wherever feasible. 7. A socioeconomic study is also conducted in this stage, and provides baseline socioeconomic and physical data: the site (only topography, location of housing, lots, etc.), the socioeconomic level of the inhabitants (income composition, employment, schooling, etc.), the sanitation and health situation (solutions used for water, sewage, and trash, health condition, most frequent diseases), identification of community resources (schools, health posts, businesses, etc.) and the different entities that are active in the area (public and private, goveniment and non-governmental), and the level of community organization (associations, types of activities). 8. This stage ends with the mobilization of the community to discuss possible interventions in water supply and sanitation. 9. Stage Two. Definition of the Productive Process. Under WDDP, no project is carried out unless the community gives its support. In Stage Two the public although not yet organized already has begun showing some interest in the program. The project design consultant team facilitates extensive discussions among the potential beneficiaries and LGU staff on possible technical alternatives for the project. This stage provides concrete information on how the project will be implemented, and discusses the technically viable options available. 10. Usually the community is divided into sectors, blocks, condominial areas, etc., for the presentation of the projects and technical alternatives, since discussion in smaller groups facilitates presentation and understanding. The meetings are conducted by teams of sociologists and engineers, with the former being responsible for mobilization and observation of community dynamics, and the latter for the technical proposal. The
 125 ANNEX 13 project Consultant team will also undertake random household visits to mobilize the public and ensure that the information has been properly understood. 11. This stage ends when the community formally commits itself to the project and decides on the technically-viable alternative that is best suited to its needs and financial possibilities. An acceptable level of commitment would be when at least 60 percent of the community sign-on to the project proposals. 12. Commitment to the project may be individual (signature of the terms of agreement) or in well-organized communities it may be agreed to by purok or barangay- level groups (i.e. minutes of meetings signed by the participants). Local NGOs active in an area must also be involved in this process. 13. The first two stages are estimated to take an average of between two to four months. 14. Stage Three. Implementation of the construction works. The works are executed in this phase. It includes actions to promote, maintain, and consolidate the community participation process. With a view to strengthening community organization, committees of community members will be encouraged to monitor the work, and agents will be trained to disseminate information throughout the community. 15. Informal groups already active in the community (for example neighborhood women's groups), could be trained as project disseminators. Similarly, parents' association of local schools could take on the responsibility of monitoring the works. 16. At this stage, sanitary and environmental education activities by other national and LGU-based programs will be coordinated with the project activities. Sanitary and environmental education messages can be reinforced through the use of simple texts (which could frequently be prepared by the community itself), and through educational, cultural, and recreational activities, such as sports events, street theater, essay and poster contests, etc. Participants will also be encouraged to undertake income-producing activities such as craft fairs, production cooperatives, etc. 17. As for execution of the works begun in this stage, local labor will be used whenever possible, contracted by the construction companies or in the form of voluntary labor or self-construction groups. 18. This stage ends with the completion of the works. 19. Stage Four. Operation of the Systems. The sanitation systems becomes operational when the facilities are completed. Community training in the proper use and maintenance of the systems is stepped-up in this stage. Training for the disseminators will also be stepped up, so they can continue the work of sanitary education after the WDDP team has left.
 126 ANNEX 13 20. For about three months after the systems become operational, the Design and supervision team will remain in the area, reinforcing hygiene education and ensuring that communities are fulfilling their agreed responsibilities. 21. Different informal groups and voluntary organizations (church groups, mother associations, soccer clubs, youth groups etc.) active in the area will be involved at this stage because they are the ones who can give continuity to the community participation process, and ensure that the results obtained under WDDP get fully internalized within communities. 22. Initially a follow-up study was planned in order to identify the changes that took place in the projects. However, on review, the project preparation team felt that to perform a second study three months after the systems become operational is inadequate time for evaluating the sustainability of investments. 23. Stage Five. Evaluation. This is not a separate stage. It takes place on two levels during the entire process (as discussed in Annex 8) and involves: 24. Public evaluation of project performance with the help of the multi-disciplinary project team; identifying difficulties, suggesting solutions, and examining results. 25. Technical evaluation of the project team evaluates the procedures followed, and verifies whether the construction activities are in consonance with community wishes. IV. Role of the Consultants 26. Under WDDP, the LGU and Water District staff will be responsible for ensuring that community participation actually takes place. The actual community participation will be conducted during the detailed engineering design process by the Design and Supervision Consultant. The LGUs and WDs do not have the institutional capacity to undertake such a complex process. The Design and Supervision Consultant's terms of reference spell out the detailed requirements(see Annex 12). 27. All community participation projects will be executed by a team consisting of civil engineers, community participation specialists (with local knowledge of the area) and LGU representatives. The task of mobilizing a suitable team is the responsibility of the Design and Supervision Consultant. 28. The teams hired by the agents or consultants will receive initial training from PMO/CPSO with assistance from the Bank, so that they can familiarize themselves with the program's methodology, providing information, and standardizing procedures to be followed. CPSO LWUA, the Bank team, PMO and LGU-based PMU staff will participate in this training exercise soon after selection of the Design and Supervision Consultant. The topics to be covered in the seminar will include: (a) information about WDDP rules;
 127 ANNEX 13 (b) information about the proposed methodology for the community participation projects; (c) information about the technical engineering project, and (d) information about the areas where the work was to be carried out.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Water Districts Development Project are to: 1) help participating local governments and water districts plan and implement sewerage and sanitation investments; and 2) assist the Phillippine government in developing transparent regulatory mechanisms in order to facilitate private sector participation in water utilities. The project consists of two components, financed by two loans. The first loan will finance the Public Performance Audit (PPA component), comprising technical assistance designed to pilot and field-test a privatized public performance audit system. Independent auditors will monitor, evaluate, and publicly report the performance of the two consessionaires who have been awarded the contracts to manage metro Manila's water supply and sanitation infrastructure. The second loan will finance the Sewerage, Sanitation, and Drainage component (the SSD component), consisting of constructing sewerage, sanitation, and drainage infrastructure in the cities of Davao, Cotabato, Calamba, and Cagayan de Oro.
